channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

Author Correction: Nuclear genetic control of mtDNA copy number and heteroplasmy in humans
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Nuclear genetic control of mtDNA copy number and heteroplasmy in humans

item.title: I breed and release Arctic foxes to boost their numbers in the wild
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01592-6

Over the past 25 years, Kristine Ulvund has helped to increase the species’ population size from 50 or so individuals to more than 500.
item.dc:title: I breed and release Arctic foxes to boost their numbers in the wild
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Observation of Bose–Einstein condensation of dipolar molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07492-z

Bose–Einstein condensate of sodium–caesium molecules is observed by means of evaporative cooling and collisional shielding.
item.dc:title: Observation of Bose–Einstein condensation of dipolar molecules
item.dc:creator: Niccolò Bigagli
Weijun Yuan
Siwei Zhang
Boris Bulatovic
Tijs Karman
Ian Stevenson
Sebastian Will

item.title: We pulled together for ocean science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01660-x

Isabelle Côté and three other female marine scientists competed in a row across the Atlantic ocean, making the trip in 38 days to raise money for ocean education, conservation and research.
item.dc:title: We pulled together for ocean science
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Why cicadas shriek so loudly and more: your questions answered
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01621-4

Billions of the insects are making an epic emergence in the eastern United States.
item.dc:title: Why cicadas shriek so loudly and more: your questions answered
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Using live transport data to deliver sustainable cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01669-2

Smart cities rely on digital technologies to keep goods and people moving at a lower cost to the planet. The world needs more of them.
item.dc:title: Using live transport data to deliver sustainable cities
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: ‘Preposterous’: Anthony Fauci denies cover-up of COVID origins during tense hearing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01657-6

Long-awaited testimony ends in fireworks as US lawmakers spar over the former infectious-disease official’s pandemic actions.
item.dc:title: ‘Preposterous’: Anthony Fauci denies cover-up of COVID origins during tense hearing
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov
Lauren Wolf

item.title: How to keep the lights on: the mission to make more photostable fluorophores
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01591-7

Fluorescent labels that have greater resistance to bleaching could help researchers to get more from biological imaging.
item.dc:title: How to keep the lights on: the mission to make more photostable fluorophores
item.dc:creator: Ariana Remmel

item.title: Physicists coax molecules into exotic quantum state — ending decades-long quest
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01662-9

Molecular Bose–Einstein condensates could help to provide the answers to fundamental questions, or form the basis of new quantum computers.
item.dc:title: Physicists coax molecules into exotic quantum state — ending decades-long quest
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Hope for global pandemic treaty rises — despite missed deadline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01658-5

Delegates were at an impasse over key issues, but agreements on other public-health emergency measures sparks cautious optimism.
item.dc:title: Hope for global pandemic treaty rises — despite missed deadline
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Sex hormones in the gut soar during pregnancy — thanks to busy bacteria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01531-5

Two species in the gut microbiome transform corticosteroids into progestins, which can affect mood and behaviour.
item.dc:title: Sex hormones in the gut soar during pregnancy — thanks to busy bacteria

item.title: First pig-to-human liver transplant recipient ‘doing very well’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01613-4

The transplant aims to prolong the life of the patient and provides important lessons for doctors.
item.dc:title: First pig-to-human liver transplant recipient ‘doing very well’
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: Biomedical paper retractions have quadrupled in 20 years — why?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01609-0

Unreliable data, falsification and other issues related to misconduct are driving a growing proportion of retractions.
item.dc:title: Biomedical paper retractions have quadrupled in 20 years — why?
item.dc:creator: Holly Else

item.title: How I run a virtual lab group that’s collaborative, inclusive and productive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01620-5

Despite having no fixed address, my team has been able to work together to create impactful science.
item.dc:title: How I run a virtual lab group that’s collaborative, inclusive and productive
item.dc:creator: Luisa Maria Diele-Viegas

item.title: Biggest genome ever found belongs to this odd little plant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01567-7

The gigantic genome of a type of fork fern smashes the human one in terms of size.
item.dc:title: Biggest genome ever found belongs to this odd little plant
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: What is science? Tech heavyweights brawl over definition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01626-z

AI pioneer Yann LeCun and Elon Musk went head-to-head in a debate about modern research that drew thousands of comments.
item.dc:title: What is science? Tech heavyweights brawl over definition
item.dc:creator: Fred Schwaller

item.title: Daily briefing: If you do research and don’t publish it, is it science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01664-7

Tech heavyweights brawl over whether research needs to be published to count as science. Plus, the first recipient of a gene-edited pig liver is ‘doing very well’ and how Viking-age hunters took down the world’s biggest animal.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: If you do research and don’t publish it, is it science?
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: The cicadas are here! Why US researchers are swarming to study them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01584-6

Two particular broods of the insects are popping up together for the first time in two centuries, and there’s a lot we don’t know about them.
item.dc:title: The cicadas are here! Why US researchers are swarming to study them
item.dc:creator: Sumeet Kulkarni

item.title: Karaoke-related stress soars after a good night of REM sleep
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01532-4

The emotional load of listening to one’s own performance is preserved by a certain type of sleep.
item.dc:title: Karaoke-related stress soars after a good night of REM sleep

item.title: More than a billion people live in ‘energy poverty’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01530-6

Satellite data help to show that many people with access to electricity cannot take advantage of it.
item.dc:title: More than a billion people live in ‘energy poverty’

item.title: How I overcame my stage fright in the lab
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01616-1

Kwabena Boahen Asare was determined to conquer his fear of public speaking after landing a research placement that required him to give weekly presentations.
item.dc:title: How I overcame my stage fright in the lab
item.dc:creator: Kwabena Asare

item.title: Japan’s push to make all research open access is taking shape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01493-8

Japan will start allocating the ¥10 billion it promised to spend on institutional repositories to make the nation’s science free to read.
item.dc:title: Japan’s push to make all research open access is taking shape
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Defying the stereotype of Black resilience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01611-6

As head of the Black In Neuro network, Kaela S. Singleton argues that Black success should not require hardship or struggle.
item.dc:title: Defying the stereotype of Black resilience
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan

item.title: Mexico’s next president will be a scientist — researchers are split in their support
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01583-7

Some are hopeful, but others worry that Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo will follow in her controversial predecessor’s footsteps rather than stand up for science.
item.dc:title: Mexico’s next president will be a scientist — researchers are split in their support
item.dc:creator: Humberto Basilio

item.title: Measuring the forces that shape early human embryos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01556-w

Contractile forces at the surface of cells of early human embryos bring the cells together. When these forces are absent, the embryo will not develop further. ‘Weak’ cells do not produce these forces and cannot contribute to the embryo. These observations should influence clinical choices during assisted reproductive-technology procedures.
item.dc:title: Measuring the forces that shape early human embryos

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Smart’ antibiotic spares the microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01639-8

The antibiotic lolamicin targets disease-causing bacteria without disturbing healthy gut bacteria. Plus, the underground lab that will test a controversial dark-matter claim and how NASA astronauts train to walk on the Moon.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Smart’ antibiotic spares the microbiome
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Disputed dark-matter claim to be tested by new lab in South Korea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01347-3

A multi-million dollar facility is hoping to put a 21-year-old debate about dark matter to rest.
item.dc:title: Disputed dark-matter claim to be tested by new lab in South Korea
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Innovative cancer therapies offer new hope
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01425-6

The arsenal of weapons used to treat these insidious diseases is rapidly expanding.
item.dc:title: Innovative cancer therapies offer new hope
item.dc:creator: Herb Brody

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals extinct flightless bird’s superpowers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01529-z

The little bush moa had small eyes, no wings and some extraordinary skills.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals extinct flightless bird’s superpowers

item.title: Chance of heatwaves in India rising with climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01577-5

Not only are these extreme events increasing in frequency, they are lasting longer and becoming hotter, too.
item.dc:title: Chance of heatwaves in India rising with climate change
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: How AI could improve robotics, the cockroach’s origins, and promethium spills its secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01610-7

We round up some recent stories from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: How AI could improve robotics, the cockroach’s origins, and promethium spills its secrets
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Elizabeth Gibney
Flora Graham

item.title: A site-resolved two-dimensional quantum simulator with hundreds of trapped ions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07459-0

In this work, stable trapping of a two-dimensional Wigner crystal of above 500 ions is achieved, and the quantum simulation of 300 ions with individual state detection demonstrated.
item.dc:title: A site-resolved two-dimensional quantum simulator with hundreds of trapped ions

item.title: Heterogeneous integration of spin–photon interfaces with a CMOS platform
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07371-7

A modular quantum system-on-chip architecture integrates thousands of individually addressable spin qubits in two-dimensional quantum microchiplet arrays into an integrated circuit designed for cryogenic control, supporting full connectivity for quantum memory arrays across spin–photon channels.
item.dc:title: Heterogeneous integration of spin–photon interfaces with a CMOS platform

item.title: Transcriptional control of the Cryptosporidium life cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07466-1

The transcription factor Myb-M is the earliest determinant of male fate in the parasite Cryptosporidium parvum.
item.dc:title: Transcriptional control of the Cryptosporidium life cycle

item.title: Reproducible graphene synthesis by oxygen-free chemical vapour deposition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07454-5

Assessment of surface contamination shows that trace oxygen is a key factor influencing the trajectory and quality of graphene grown by low-pressure chemical vapour deposition, with oxygen-free synthesis showing increased reproducibility and quality.
item.dc:title: Reproducible graphene synthesis by oxygen-free chemical vapour deposition

item.title: The complete sequence and comparative analysis of ape sex chromosomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07473-2

Reference assemblies of great ape sex chromosomes show that Y chromosomes are more variable in size and sequence than X chromosomes and provide a resource for studies on human evolution and conservation genetics of non-human apes.
item.dc:title: The complete sequence and comparative analysis of ape sex chromosomes

item.title: Streamflow seasonality in a snow-dwindling world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07299-y

Analysis of streamflow measurements from 1950 to 2020 across 3,049 snow-affected catchments over the Northern Hemisphere shows that seasonal streamflow occurs earlier in snow-heavy catchments but later in less snowy regions.
item.dc:title: Streamflow seasonality in a snow-dwindling world
item.dc:creator: Juntai Han
Ziwei Liu

Ying Hou

item.title: Van der Waals polarity-engineered 3D integration of 2D complementary logic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07438-5

We develop a method for high-density vertical stacking of active-device multi-layers, implementing memory and logic functions, using unique VIP-FETs where a van der Waals intercalation layer modulates the p- or n-type nature of the FETs.
item.dc:title: Van der Waals polarity-engineered 3D integration of 2D complementary logic

item.title: A vision chip with complementary pathways for open-world sensing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07358-4

Inspired by the human visual system, a vision chip with primitive-based complementary pathways is developed to overcome the power and bandwidth wall of vision systems, achieving fast, precise, robust and high-dynamic-range sensing efficiently in the open world.
item.dc:title: A vision chip with complementary pathways for open-world sensing

item.title: Unlocking bacterial potential to reduce farmland N<sub>2</sub>O emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07464-3

A study presents a method to mitigate emissions of nitrous oxide from farmland using bacteria to consume nitrous oxide in soil with organic waste as a substrate and vector.
item.dc:title: Unlocking bacterial potential to reduce farmland N<sub>2</sub>O emissions
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth G. Hiis

Lars Molstad
Kristine Røsdal

Lars R. Bakken

item.title: Structural basis for pegRNA-guided reverse transcription by a prime editor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07497-8

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the prime editor bound to a prime editing guide RNA and target DNA, in the pre-initiation, initiation and elongation and termination states, provide insights into the mechanism by which prime editing occurs.
item.dc:title: Structural basis for pegRNA-guided reverse transcription by a prime editor
item.dc:creator: Yutaro Shuto

Osamu Nureki

item.title: Canted spin order as a platform for ultrafast conversion of magnons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07448-3

A study demonstrates a new functionality of canted spin order for magnonics and shows that it facilitates mechanisms for ultrafast nonlinear conversion of magnons.
item.dc:title: Canted spin order as a platform for ultrafast conversion of magnons
item.dc:creator: R. A. Leenders
D. Afanasiev
A. V. Kimel
R. V. Mikhaylovskiy

item.title: An alternative cell cycle coordinates multiciliated cell differentiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07476-z

A distinct cell cycle redeploys many canonical cell cycle regulators to control the differentiation of multiciliated cells, with the transcription factor E2F7 playing a pivotal part in this modified cell cycle.
item.dc:title: An alternative cell cycle coordinates multiciliated cell differentiation
item.dc:creator: Semil P. Choksi

Benedict W. H. Tsai
Rachel Deleon

Christopher J. Westlake
Jeremy F. Reiter

item.title: A Gram-negative-selective antibiotic that spares the gut microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07502-0

Lolamicin, a novel antibiotic developed from a pyridinepyrazole precursor, exhibits potent activity against a broad range of Gram-negative multidrug-resistant clinical isolates, and good efficacy in mouse models of infection without inducing gut dysbiosis.
item.dc:title: A Gram-negative-selective antibiotic that spares the gut microbiome

item.title: Nano-achiral complex composites for extreme polarization optics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07455-4

Multilayer composites of 2D nanomaterials manufactured using a layer-by-layer methodology demonstrates strong polarization rotation, mechanical robustness and operational temperatures as high as 250 °C, despite being nano-achiral and partially disordered.
item.dc:title: Nano-achiral complex composites for extreme polarization optics
item.dc:creator: Jun Lu
Wenbing Wu
Felippe Mariano Colombari
Ali Jawaid
Bryan Seymour
Kody Whisnant
Xiaoyang Zhong
Wonjin Choi
Joerg Lahann
Richard A. Vaia
André Farias de Moura
Dhriti Nepal
Nicholas A. Kotov

item.title: High-resolution in situ structures of mammalian respiratory supercomplexes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07488-9

Mammalian respiratory supercomplexes are imaged in their native membrane environment by in situ cryo-electron microscopy, providing insight into their reactive intermediates and conformational dynamics.
item.dc:title: High-resolution in situ structures of mammalian respiratory supercomplexes
item.dc:creator: Wan Zheng
Pengxin Chai
Jiapeng Zhu
Kai Zhang

item.title: Membraneless channels sieve cations in ammonia-oxidizing marine archaea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07462-5

The Nitrosopumilus maritimus surface layer (S-layer) concentrates ammonium ions on its cell-facing side, acting as a multichannel sieve on the cell membrane.
item.dc:title: Membraneless channels sieve cations in ammonia-oxidizing marine archaea
item.dc:creator: Andriko von Kügelgen
C. Keith Cassidy
Sofie van Dorst
Lennart L. Pagani
Christopher Batters
Zephyr Ford
Jan Löwe
Vikram Alva
Phillip J. Stansfeld
Tanmay A. M. Bharat

item.title: Pro-CRISPR PcrIIC1-associated Cas9 system for enhanced bacterial immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07486-x

Comprehensive analyses of Cas9 proteins shed light on the evolution of the CRISPR–Cas9 system, and identify a pro-CRISPR accessory protein in bacteria that boosts CRISPR-mediated immunity by enhancing the DNA binding and cleavage activity of Cas9.
item.dc:title: Pro-CRISPR PcrIIC1-associated Cas9 system for enhanced bacterial immunity
item.dc:creator: Shouyue Zhang
Ao Sun
Jing-Mei Qian
Shuo Lin

item.title: A contact binary satellite of the asteroid (152830) Dinkinesh
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07378-0

Observations from the Lucy spacecraft of the small main-belt asteroid (152830) Dinkinesh reveals unexpected complexity, with a longitudinal trough and equatorial ridge, as well as the discovery of the first contact binary satellite.
item.dc:title: A contact binary satellite of the asteroid (152830) Dinkinesh

item.title: Selective lignin arylation for biomass fractionation and benign bisphenols
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07446-5

By controlling C–C bond formation in catalytic arylation, lignin can be efficiently extracted from biomass and converted into benign bisphenols that can be used as replacements for their fossil-based counterparts.
item.dc:title: Selective lignin arylation for biomass fractionation and benign bisphenols
item.dc:creator: Ning Li
Kexin Yan
Thanya Rukkijakan
Jiefeng Liang

Guibin Jiang
Guangyuan Zhou

Joseph S. M. Samec
Feng Wang

item.title: Work hardening in colloidal crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07453-6

Deformation of soft colloidal crystals lead to work hardening, similar to that seen in the deformation of metals.
item.dc:title: Work hardening in colloidal crystals
item.dc:creator: Seongsoo Kim
Ilya Svetlizky
David A. Weitz
Frans Spaepen

item.title: Molecular basis for differential Igk versus Igh V(D)J joining mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07477-y

Experiments in mouse models, and in cell lines that only allow primary Vκ-to-Jκ rearrangements, enable characterization of the mechanisms of V(D)J recombination.
item.dc:title: Molecular basis for differential Igk versus Igh V(D)J joining mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Yiwen Zhang
Xiang Li
Zhaoqing Ba
Jiangman Lou
K. Elyse Gaertner
Tammie Zhu
Xin Lin
Adam Yongxin Ye
Frederick W. Alt
Hongli Hu

item.title: Acceleration of radiative recombination for efficient perovskite LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07460-7

A dual-additive crystallization method using PyNI and 5AVA as additives results in highly efficient 3D perovskite films with enhanced photoluminescence quantum efficiencies and external quantum efficiencies, and hence increased LED performance.
item.dc:title: Acceleration of radiative recombination for efficient perovskite LEDs
item.dc:creator: Mengmeng Li
Yingguo Yang
Zhiyuan Kuang

item.title: Low-latency automotive vision with event cameras
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07409-w

Use of a 20 frames per second (fps) RGB camera plus an event camera can achieve the same latency as a 5,000-fps camera with the bandwidth of a 45-fps camera without compromising accuracy.
item.dc:title: Low-latency automotive vision with event cameras
item.dc:creator: Daniel Gehrig
Davide Scaramuzza

item.title: The sex of organ geometry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07463-4

In fruit flies, three-dimensional organ arrangement is stereotypical, sexually dimorphic and actively maintained by muscle-vessel mechanochemical crosstalk.
item.dc:title: The sex of organ geometry
item.dc:creator: Laura Blackie
Pedro Gaspar
Salem Mosleh
Oleh Lushchak
Lingjin Kong
Yuhong Jin
Agata P. Zielinska
Boxuan Cao

Bryon Silva
Tomotsune Ameku
Shu En Lim
Yanlan Mao
Lucía Prieto-Godino
Todd Schoborg
Marta Varela

Irene Miguel-Aliaga

item.title: Exclusive: How NASA astronauts are training to walk on the Moon in 2026
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01533-3

Simulated lunar exploration in an Arizona volcanic field this month helped astronauts to prepare for doing geology in harsh conditions at the lunar south pole. Nature joined mission control.
item.dc:title: Exclusive: How NASA astronauts are training to walk on the Moon in 2026
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: ‘Smart’ antibiotic can kill deadly bacteria while sparing the microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01566-8

Compound called lolamicin targets a group of harmful microbes but does not disturb those that live peacefully in the gut.
item.dc:title: ‘Smart’ antibiotic can kill deadly bacteria while sparing the microbiome
item.dc:creator: Fred Schwaller

item.title: Why snow is crucial for water supply — and what will happen when it becomes scarce
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01239-6

Analysis of 70 years of snowfall in the Northern Hemisphere reveals that snow buffers the effect of varying precipitation levels on streamflow. The link highlights the need to rethink water-resource management as snow levels decline.
item.dc:title: Why snow is crucial for water supply — and what will happen when it becomes scarce
item.dc:creator: Karen R. Ryberg

item.title: It’s time for your performance review
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01527-1

Cooking up a storm.
item.dc:title: It’s time for your performance review
item.dc:creator: Jane Brown

item.title: Advances in highly targeted radiation treatment for cancer have ignited interest in a once obscure field
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01428-3

Therapies that treat while diagnosing — theranostics — can extend length of survival and improve the quality of life for some people with advance-stage cancer.
item.dc:title: Advances in highly targeted radiation treatment for cancer have ignited interest in a once obscure field
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: A myopia epidemic is sweeping the globe. Here’s how to stop it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01518-2

Time spent outdoors is the best defence against rising rates of short-sightedness, but scientists are searching for other ways to reverse the troubling trend.
item.dc:title: A myopia epidemic is sweeping the globe. Here’s how to stop it
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Randomized trials of cancer drugs are for yesterday
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01430-9

Pitting new treatments against old, ineffective agents is neither ethical nor economical.
item.dc:title: Randomized trials of cancer drugs are for yesterday
item.dc:creator: Elaine Schattner

item.title: How antibody–drug conjugates aim to take down cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01426-5

Scientists are trying to work out how to balance potency with toxicity and tackle the cost of next-generation therapeutics.
item.dc:title: How antibody–drug conjugates aim to take down cancer
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: Monkey business: primates’ social life tracked with wireless neuronal recording
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00467-0

Primates have rich social lives orchestrated by brain circuits that are still poorly understood, partly because they have not been studied under naturalistic conditions. New wireless technology for recording neuronal activity in freely moving monkeys enabled insights into how neurons track natural social interactions, including reciprocity and social support towards a partner.
item.dc:title: Monkey business: primates’ social life tracked with wireless neuronal recording

item.title: Turning tumours against themselves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01429-2

Advances in in situ therapeutic cancer vaccines offer a mode of treatment that could redeem the promise of previous false dawns.
item.dc:title: Turning tumours against themselves
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: Daily briefing: Autism triples risk of Parkinson’s-like symptoms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01615-2

People with autism, intellectual disabilities or both are three times more likely than the general population to develop Parkinson’s-like symptoms as they age. Plus, a study seems to cast doubt on the theory that sleep cleanses the brain and what to do when funding runs out.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Autism triples risk of Parkinson’s-like symptoms
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Nature’s message to South Africa’s next government: talk to your researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01516-4

The young nation faces some deep-rooted challenges. Solutions informed by science could make a difference.
item.dc:title: Nature’s message to South Africa’s next government: talk to your researchers

item.title: Baobab trees’ evolutionary history could inform conservation efforts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01549-9

The genomes of all eight living species of baobab tree (Adansonia sp.) reveal the group’s origin and diversification history. Ecological analyses were incorporated to characterize the baobabs’ past population dynamics and were used to propose protection measures for these iconic species, including the reassessment of their conservation status and the close monitoring of several of Madagascar’s baobab species.
item.dc:title: Baobab trees’ evolutionary history could inform conservation efforts

item.title: Nitrogen-hungry bacteria added to farm soil curb greenhouse-gas emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01363-3

Innovative solutions are needed to decrease greenhouse-gas emissions. Field trials show that supplementing farm soil with a bacterium that consumes the greenhouse gas nitrous oxide can substantially lower harmful emissions.
item.dc:title: Nitrogen-hungry bacteria added to farm soil curb greenhouse-gas emissions
item.dc:creator: Guang He
Frank E. Löffler

item.title: AI assistance for planning cancer treatment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01431-8

Armed with the right data, advances in machine learning could help oncologists to home in quickly on the best treatment strategies for their patients.
item.dc:title: AI assistance for planning cancer treatment
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: Microbes ‘sieve’ ions on their surface to start the nitrogen cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01351-7

Uptake of ammonium ions by marine microorganisms called archaea is a key first step in the conversion of ammonium to nitrogen found in ecosystems. Structural evidence reveals how archaea capture ammonium in an efficient way.
item.dc:title: Microbes ‘sieve’ ions on their surface to start the nitrogen cycle
item.dc:creator: Henry van den Bedem

item.title: Natural killer cells show their cancer-fighting worth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01427-4

Although natural-killer-cell therapies are safer than T-cell therapies and offer other advantages, they require upgrades to overcome their limited lifespan and susceptibility to immunosuppression.
item.dc:title: Natural killer cells show their cancer-fighting worth
item.dc:creator: Amanda B. Keener
